DOC.HEAD: China Charges Five With Helping Dissidents Flee
DOC.TEXT: China says it arrested five Hong Kong and Macao residents on charges of trying to smuggle dissidents out of the country and today accused a Hong Kong group of running an ``underground railroad.'' China said the Hong Kong Alliance for Supporting the Democratic Movement in China helped dozens of dissidents flee abroad since the army crackdown on pro-democracy protests in June. Police said the arrests ``dealt a major blow to the overseas reactionary forces who attempted to use Hong Kong and Macao as sanctuaries for criminals,'' the official Xinhua News Agency said in a report Monday. The five arrests were made over the past three months, and Xinhua did not say why they were being announced only now. It said China will ``punish severely those who dare to plot and ship wanted criminals out of the mainland.'' China has said repeatedly it will not allow residents of Hong Kong and Macao to interfere in mainland affairs, but this was the first time it explicitly accused the Hong Kong alliance of running the underground railroad. The alliance was founded after the June crackdown, which increased anxiety in British-ruled Hong Kong and Portuguese-ruled Macao about their return to Chinese rule in the coming decade. The official People's Daily defended the arrests in an editorial in today's editions, saying ``Hong Kong and Macao residents must obey Chinese laws when on the mainland.'' In excerpts of the editorial, the paper accused the alliance of smuggling abroad ``important counter-revolutionary criminals. ... The Chinese government will never tolerate such activities.'' China considers ethnic Chinese from the two colonies to be Chinese citizens and has rejected past efforts by Britain to intervene on behalf of arrested Hong Kong Chinese. The arrests were likely to increase Hong Kong fears about Chinese rule, which already have sent many in search of haven elsewhere.
